reviews.review_msg: CMPT 373 is a very difficult course with a lot of components due each week, most importantly being semester-long the group project and the exercises. Nick is very knowledgeable on the topics though, and gives great feedback on exercises and the group project. You will need to put in a ton of work to do well, but you will learn a ton in return.

Please don't be discouraged by the negative reviews here. CMPT 373 is not an easy course, but you will learn so so much. Nick expects a lot from you, but is always easily accessible through office hours and coursys, so it's easy to get your questions answered. This class is not a GPA booster, but it will make you a much MUCH stronger programmer.

Gives way too much work. Be prepared for multiple assignments a week, at least 100 lines per week of code for the group project, and low average exams. Overwhelming workload. Exercises are difficult if you haven't mastered C++

I think the professor expects a lot from students in terms of previous course knowledge (C++ specifically). Yet, they regularly admit to critical information going untaught in required courses for the majority of those enrolled, even though it is supposedly a part of the “curriculum”, as he says. With all that said, he still doesn't relax :(

Literally the worst class I ever took, there are 2 assignments due every week which he thinks all the students learned from cmpt 130 and saying everyone should know already. Does not really answers the question when its asked all he says is "I will not recommend to do" but does not give any suggestion what is good. I would wait for different prof

Honestly, this was a great course. Nick makes it clear from the first lecture that it's not a cake walk. He is very caring and understanding in his expectations (giving several extensions through this semester) and is very accessible and approachable outside of class. The focus was on practical software dev skills, a nice change from other courses.

Course is way too heavy, too dependent on cpp, with high pre-req expectations. A simple assignment will take whole week. If you are not good with c++, you wont pass. Grp project, assignments, code reviews, readings, keep juggling between them. 
Prof is great though, knowledgeable, but course was not designed properly

There are way too many things packed into this course. Unless you have years of experience with C++ this will be a heavy course load. Final exam is 1 day right after a huge term project is due. Absolutely no time to prepare for the exam at all.

It's obvious he knows his stuff, however, I do not think I have ever been so stressed from a class before. Exercises take way too much time and the project is also difficult since we have to juggle between the exercises, the final exam, and other classes. You will definitely learn a lot by taking this professor but be prepared for the worst.

He's honestly a great prof. He knows his stuff and probably has Coursys discussions setup on his phone.

Only issue is, this class is basically C++ advanced tips & tricks. It focuses way more on doing certain things in C++ and the exercises are basically C++ death sentences. If you love C++, then great! If you don't? Then you end up like me.
Great knowledgeable professor, but I think he overestimate what students already know. Kind off overloaded course.
super enthusiastic and knowledgeable. not easy but a great class.

Not too sure why Nick has such a low rating.

This class is a bit slow on returning grades back to students; However, aside from that, I feel like Nick is an excellent prof. It seems like he genuinely cares that his students learn.

If you want an easy A then I would avoid. If you want to actually learn, then consider taking this course.
37% avg finals. 3+ deadlines every week. grades take 2 months to return. recommend to avoid for a more balanced instructor.

Sumner's biggest failure is in admin/delayed marking, 100%. Otherwise, he's overall an 11 / 10 prof. Super knowledgeable. His exercises + content are AMAZING, they make you really understand the material you learn. Much of which he made on the fly, as he restructured the course entirely scaling from 16 -> 80 ppl. Project was tough, with big classes

Don't make a mistake of taking this course with him. Unorganized, No clear grading criteria, Vague answers, sorry to say but he promised that grades of individual assignments will be out which never did making him a lier. U'll talk about this course in interviews, don't make your life harder but taking it with him when outcome is nothing.

Please don't do this to yourself. u'll not even end up with crappy C++ project and outcome of this course is just 5 design patterns. You will not receive any grades back so u will never know how well u r doing. No doubt he is knowledgable but this doesn't mean he can teach well. He uses tech-jargon so much that you won't understand a thing. AVOID

I wanted to like this prof more. He was enthusiastic and knowlegable about the content, but he explained the concepts poorly. The project was overly ambitious and difficult. I learned of C++ though. He was lacking in the administrative side, being very late in grading and providing assignments. He also expected us to know more than was reasonable.

Taking CMPT 373 with Nick was challenging, but I enjoyed it overall. The school curriculum clearly didn't meet his expectations on what students should know about C++ by third year, but rather than let us get bad grades, he adapted his curriculum to teach us everything we needed to know and made assignments easier. He's a good guy and clever prof.

Professor Sumner, if you are reading this I genuinely learned a bunch from your class. But, the common theme seems like a lot of students don't know their grade during the course. It obviously was like this also during CMPT373 where no grades were really returned until after the exam. Regardless, Professor Sumner is an extremely knowledgeable prof.

There's a reason why he has a high rating. His recorded lectures were fantastic and great to listen to and follow along. Very enthusiastic about topics, and I genuinely enjoyed the course. Takes feedback seriously to better improve his course. Has systems in place to ensure everyone is marked fairly for projects, thus you'll get what you put in.

Dr. Brian Fraser is the best prof at SFU! My favorite thing about him is that he makes students who speak up in class who don't give the right answer still feel valued and conveys that what they have to say is considered and important. I feel this makes a big difference to students. Every prof at SFU should strive to be as enthusiastic as Dr. Brian

The superlatives you read below are true: Dr Fraser is a top tier instructor, and perhaps more importantly, an amazing person. Funny and engaging lectures. Listens to feedback, taking surveys and reviewing results in class. Empathetic towards students especially during the pandemic. High workload but you receive valuable and practical education.
Honestly, the best prof you can ask for.

Overall, Brian is not the worst prof for this class. But his project's grading was weird and ambiguous, so try to do some stupid things, like code reviews, to boost your grade. Also, you should be ready to write long responses to an outdated book about software development.
Awesome prof
The best prof at SFU. He is very clear, caring and knowledgable. Love him. Definitely recommend him.

Pros:  -group project is very useful (agile development method is used pretty much everywhere now) -lectures are crystal clear -kind and generous in general and very open to feedback from students  Cons: -quizzes are VERY tricky
